rules.name: Avoid SELECT *
rules.description: Using SELECT * in SQL statements is not recommended as it can lead to performance issues and makes code harder to maintain.
rules.suggestion: Specify column names explicitly instead of using SELECT *

rules.name: Error handling required
rules.description: All file operations should have proper error handling to ensure robust code.
rules.suggestion: Add error handling using %ERROR() or indicator (e.g., *IN99)

rules.name: Avoid hardcoded values
rules.description: Hardcoded values should be replaced with named constants for better maintainability.
rules.suggestion: Define a named constant instead of using hardcoded values

rules.name: Use qualified data structure names
rules.description: Using qualified data structure names improves code readability and prevents naming conflicts.
rules.suggestion: Add QUALIFIED keyword to data structure definitions

rules.name: Avoid magic numbers
rules.description: Magic numbers (unnamed numeric literals) make code harder to understand and maintain.
rules.suggestion: Replace magic numbers with named constants

rules.name: Procedure documentation required
rules.description: All procedures should have documentation comments explaining their purpose and parameters.
rules.suggestion: Add documentation comments before procedure declaration

rules.name: Avoid obsolete operation codes
rules.description: Some operation codes are obsolete and should be replaced with modern alternatives.
rules.suggestion: Use EVAL or modern built-in functions instead

rules.name: Use built-in functions
rules.description: Built-in functions (BIFs) are more efficient and readable than traditional operation codes.

rules.name: Avoid open access files
rules.description: Files should be explicitly opened and closed for better resource management.
rules.suggestion: Use OPEN and CLOSE operations explicitly

rules.name: Use constants for literal values
rules.description: Frequently used literal values should be defined as constants.
rules.suggestion: Define a constant for this literal value
